headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Ryan Zinke is Interviewed about the House Speaker Voting; Actions to Take for Cardiac Arrest; China Accused of Underrepresenting Outbreak. Aired 6:30-7a ET

utterances.speaker: KAITLIN COLLINS, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Ha rejected former President Trump's call to support Kevin McCarthy for speaker.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. LAUREN BOEBERT (R-CO): The president needs to tell Kevin McCarthy that, sir, you do not have the votes and it's time to withdrawal. With that, I yield. Thank you. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Democrats have really just been watching all of this play out.Congressman Jimmy Gomez of California was pulling double duty, caring for his four month old son during these long hours on Capitol Hill, sharing this picture in his new office after a fresh diaper change. Then there was also this moment with Republican Kat Cammack's speech to nominate McCarthy for the sixth ballot for speaker, one that failed, getting this reaction from Democrats. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. KAT CAMMACK (R-FL): They want us divided. They want us to fight each other. That much has been made clear by the popcorn and blankets and alcohol that is coming over there. The House is not in order. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: The House is definitely not in order. The House reconvene at noon today to take another stab at electing a speaker. But the longer it goes on, the more time for Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, who says her dog was napping during all of this.Lawmakers return today. Still no speaker. Evident here, the name on the door above the speaker's office. There is no name. Kevin McCarthy has moved into that office, but the question is, whether or not he will remain in that office after he took up residence there a few days ago. Maybe a little too early. So, to talk about all of this as we are awaiting for lawmakers to return today is Republican Congressman-elect Ryan Zinke of Montana, who is the former interior secretary under former President Trump. He has voted for McCarthy six times. I imagine you will be voting for him again today? RYAN ZINKE (R), MONTANA CONG.-ELECT: Again. You know, and it's really not about a speaker at this point. It's whether the Republicans can actually govern.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Can they?

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: I believe they can. I think we'll get there. But, you know, I'm a former SEAL and I've been to a lot of battles in my life. I can tell you, not every battle is led by, you know, George C. Patton. But we win because we step up. Because generals don't win wars, it's the front line. And in this city, it isn't the speaker that passes the bills, it's the front line, it's the body, it's the chair and the members that all have a say.So, who the speaker is has to make sure that he has the votes, but also listen to the body. And we're not - we're not there yet. I support Kevin because 90 percent of the caucus voted. And it's like a primary. With 90 percent of the body supporting an individual, in this case Kevin McCarthy. You have a small minority that are outcasts. And what are the demands? Up front, what do they want? Can't tell you. Because they just don't like Kevin. There's a trust issue. But there's also a trust issue with the body, with the 20. So it - now it's more about trust and rather than, you know, a leadership.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, Kevin McCarthy made these several major concessions overnight. Is that enough to get him to 218?

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: You know, we'll see. But he's made concessions before on a rule package, you know, how you conduct, how - how -- what's the threshold to vacate the chair. You know, all of us want the same thing. We want to make sure we hold the government accountable. We want to make sure fiscally we have discipline because we have not. But we can't begin this process until we have a speaker in place. That's the first step. So, we can't begin to defend, in Montana's case, we have rules, you know, waters of the U.S., there's gun infringement, Second Amendment infringement, a lot of things that each state finds important. We can't even begin that process until we have a speaker.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But it's not clear to you right now, as of, you know, 6

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: That's correct. And if it's a change of rules, remember the speaker himself doesn't dictate rules. That has to go to the body and the body votes on it.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: It's going to be - it's going to be an interesting day. COLLINSthe morning. Can he eventually get to 218? Do you have confidence he'll actually get there in the end of it?

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: I do because the consequence of not - and, again, it's not about Kevin. It's really about whether we can govern. So, will we have the same problem with a different candidate? Likely.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well, Matt Rosendale is the other representative from Montana. He is not supporting Kevin McCarthy. He is one of those no vote. Is that a mistake in your view?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Do you think what's happening right now with Republicans is embarrassing?

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: I think it's embarrassing. I do. And there - there is - now there's a lot of hard feelings on both sides. Again, you have 90 percent of the caucus, 90 percent of the caucus standing firmly behind Kevin McCarthy. Is he perfect? No. I don't - I don't think anyone is perfect. But how you win battles is you leverage the chairman, you leverage the members, you listen to members and lead forward and articulate what is it the Republicans -- what's our goal? And our goal is to curb inflation, to make sure we have a border, to make sure we use the power of the purse judicially and stop the excessive spending. Again, we can't even begin that process until we have a speaker.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You used to work for Trump.

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: He told all Republicans yesterday they should vote for McCarthy. McCarthy actually lost some support yesterday. Does Trump have any influence over what happens here with the Republican speaker?

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: Well, and what's the influence of the outliers, because Jim Jordan is for Kevin McCarthy. More than half the Freedom Caucus is for Kevin McCarthy. So, what is their base? Where do they get their base of support? Certainly not from President Trump. It's not from Jim Jordan. So, who are they going to rally around? Now, a lot of it too are sound bites. You look in the hallway, a lot of these members have - have not been irrelevant but certainly haven't been, you know, a media -- media icons right now. And you look at - they fall -- they go around the hall and there's, you know, a big mob of media. So, they're getting their time in -- in, quote, the press and they're making money off of it. So, they're, you know, fundraising.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But I want to go back to Trump. Does he have influence on this or does he not?

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: Well, we'll see. Certainly yesterday he did not have influence because it really didn't change any votes. And, you know, I - I worked for him. There's a couple of things that President Trump probably finds to be, you know, an irritant is one to be ignored, and two to be called out, because he was called out, not only --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: By Lauren Boebert.

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: By Lauren -- absolutely. And he has supported her in the past. I'm not sure he'll continue to support her, you know, going forward.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: We'll wait to make - we'll see.Congressman-elect, as you still are since you have not been sworn in, thank you so much for joining us this morning and talking about this.

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: My pleasure.I remain an optimist because the consequence of not having a leader, the consequence of not governing, I think, is too great. So, I remain an optimistic.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Is that he will get sworn in. Yes.All right, thank you so much for your time this morning.

utterances.speaker: ZINKE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: Yes, so -

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right, Don and Poppy.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I think we agree on a lot. Can we take that down because I want to talk about this.So, I think that with Zinke we agree on a lot. I think airing the dirty laundry is right. Nothing is getting done.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Your Harry point too.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Right, which was my point with Harry. And now all of a sudden the cameras are trained on these people who are getting attention and now they're getting this attention and they're embarrassing themselves. That's exactly what has happened now.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, where do we go from here?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Where do we go from here? Chaos until they figure out who the speaker is, because nothing is going to get done until they figure that out.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Nothing. Nothing.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And so that is the - that's --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Like critical business for the American people.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. And that's the next, for how many years .But there's a part of it, though, we'll talk about it in the political thing. This is what some Republicans wanted. So, you -- you've got to see it play out because that's who they elected. And they want to see their leaders, whether you like it or not, have influence. And those leaders now, that they elected to Congress, are having - are exerting their influence. And so -

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Kaitlan's been asking the most important question the whole time -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: What does this say about how they will lead.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: How they will lead.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: That's the question. OK, so we'll - we'll get to that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, we'll get to that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Also, CPR was given, as you know, to Bills player Damar Hamlin after he collapsed, and that is probably what saved his life, right, those critical minutes. Next, our medical expert, Dr. Tara Narula is here. She's going to show us all what you can do if you're there when something like this happens.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Welcome back, everyone, to CNN THIS MORNING.Well, this morning, Buffalo Bills safety Damar Hamlin remains in critical condition after suffering a cardiac arrest on the field during Monday night's game. The Bills say that he is showing some signs of improvement. This is an NFL executive is praising the work of the medical team who resuscitated Hamlin. Watch this. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TROY VINCENT, NFL EXECUTIVE VP OF FOOTBALL OPERATIONS
utterances.sentences: That emergency action plan was executed to perfection, by individuals who rehearsed and practiced and trained for in-stadium health emergencies. And Dr. Sills and to the medical professionals, first responders, to physicians to trainers, the EMTS, that evening was outstanding. You gave our brother, Damar, another day to live, another chance to fight.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: So much emotion around this.Let's discuss, though, the importance of CPR because Dr. Tara Narula is here. He, obviously, was administered CPR. DR. TARA NARULA, CNN MEDICAL CORRESPONDENT: Yes.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: It is so important. I mean, would you know what to do if someone in the studio went down, if someone at home went down? And three quarters of out of hospital arrests occur really at home. So, it's typically going to be a loved one, a friend, a co-worker. We know, in general, there's about 350,000 out of hospital sudden cardiac arrests a year, and the survival is so low. It's about one in ten that survive.But with bystander CPR you can increase someone's chances of survival by about two to three times. And, in fact, every minute that goes by that you don't restore a heartbeat, their chances of survival drop by about 7 to 10 percent. And, unfortunately, in this country, the rates of bystander CPR are really low. We're talking in general around 40 percent. So, we really need to do a better job as a country about really pushing people to get educated in CPR. And one of the greatest things they can learn is hands only CPR. I mean a lot of people think they have to give breaths. You don't. You can do hands only CPR.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, can we - let - I'm so glad you brought this in.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Should we -- let's start with adults -

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because it's different for babies. So, I want to get to that. But let's start with adults.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Sure. So, if you see someone go down, first, you want to make sure that the scene is safe, right? Next step is to really call 911. And then you're going to push hard and fast in the center of the chest. And so the best way to do this is to take the palm of your hand, place it here in between where the nipples are, put the other hand over, elbows locked, shoulders over, and you're going to push down hard and fast. You're pushing down to depress the chest by about two inches. So, this is a significant amount of force you're applying.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Harder than you think, right?

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Harder than you think. And you're going to do this at a rate of about 100 to 120 beats per minute. So, we talk about thinking of songs to help you kind of keep the beat.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: The American Heart Association has a play list called "Don't Drop the Beat." One of the classics songs is "Staying Alive" by the Bee Gees.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: It sounds weird but it's true. This helps.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Ah, ah, ah, ah - I mean I'm not a good singer but -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Staying alive.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But do it. That's how fast.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Right. "Staying Alive," that's exactly -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Is the beats per minutes.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Exactly. And that's what you want to keep in your head. So, that is a great way. And so you're going to do hands only CPR, 911 is being called, and then, obviously, if you have access to a defibrillator, that's really a great thing to have too. And a lot of people don't. They're scared. What's in the blue box. They don't know how to apply it. Again, rates of defibrillator use in settings of --

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Easy, one, two, three.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Correct. It's so simple. So, it tells you, turn on. You're going to push the button and turn it on. OK. You're going to take out the pads and, look, it's --

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Apply pads to patient's bear chest. Plug in pads connector next to the flashing light.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: It shows you where to place the pads. So here - yes, here. It shows you this pad. It shows you where to put this pad. You're going to plug this in.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Apply pads. Plug in connecter.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: OK. So, Poppy, I don't know if you want to help me plug that in. And then essentially -

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Analyze heart rhythm.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: It's going to analyze the heart rhythm. If it detects a rhythm that's shockable.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Do not touch the patient,

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: It tells you don't touch the patient. It's going to do it -- deliver a shock. OK.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Shock advised.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: It knows what to do.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: OK, shock advised. So you're going to push the button.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Charging.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Charging. Everyone stays clear of the patient.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Be clear of patient.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: I mean, literally, it's walking you through every step.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Deliver shock now. Press the orange button now.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Poppy.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Shock delivered.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Correct. That's it. As soon as the shock's delivered.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Begin CPR.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Begin CPR. You go back to giving CPR.

utterances.speaker: DEFIBRILLATOR AUDIO
utterances.sentences: Begin CPR.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: You do that for two minutes. And then it's going to analyze the rhythm again.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: So, I just want people to understand -

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You leave the pads as you're doing the - yes.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: You leave the pads. Yes. And this has to go on the bare chest, right.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Right.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: So if someone's clothed, you want to take that off.But this is so easy. So, people should not be afraid. Don't be afraid to give hands only CPR. Don't be afraid to use the defibrillator.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: You can save a life.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And for babies, two fingers?

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: For babies it's two fingers, yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, and you press down. It's easier for the baby. I learned that during lifeguard training, I got it, because I've never - like, you don't update it. You need to update and you need to practice.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: You need to have it in your brain so that if it happens and you're panicked, you have those skills in your mind, you know how to start doing it.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This was very helpful. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: This is the most useful thing I have seen in weeks.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes, very helpful.Thank you, Doctor.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: NARULA
utterances.sentences: Thank you, guys.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: So, this morning, global health officials are urging China to be a whole lot more transparent about the severity of their Covid outbreak. This comes as China's hospitals are overwhelmed with Covid cases after strict restrictions were abruptly reversed.Our Ivan Watson reports. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) IVAN WATSON, CNN SENIOR INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice over): Hospital hallways crowded with sick people, patients treated on sidewalks and lines of vans waiting for entry to busy funeral homes. A huge Covid-19 outbreak is battering China. The surge coming more than three years after the virus was first detected in the Chinese city of Wuhan. Chinese state television says medical workers are stepping up to meet the challenge. UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE (through translator): We have expanded the ward, added more beds. We've brought in experienced doctors to work with the young ones to get them up to speed quicker.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Last month, CNN journalists filmed bodies stored in containers awaiting cremation at one Beijing funeral home. The World Health Organization criticizing China for underrepresenting the severity of its outbreak and not sharing enough real data on the scale of the outbreak.DR. MIKE RYAN, EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR FOR HEALTH EMERGENCIES, WHO: We believe that the current numbers being published from - from China underrepresents the true impact of the disease in terms of hospital admissions, in terms of ICU admissions, and particularly in terms of deaths. And we would like to see more data on a more geographic basis across China.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Beijing's decision to allow citizens to travel internationally, ending years of self-imposed isolation, just as the virus spreads out of control has triggered a global debate. A growing number of governments imposing travel restrictions, ranging from the U.S., which requires pre-flight Covid tests, to Morocco, which temporarily banned all travel from China. Beijing is now threatening reciprocal measures.The growing international dispute of little concern to Chinese families that are struggling with the sudden loss of loved ones. Some statistical models predict China could lose more than a million people due to Covid-19. (END VIDEOTAPE) WATSON: Now, Poppy and Don, I can't stress enough what a dramatic u- turn mainland China has been through. A month ago we were talking about desperate Chines people trapped in lockdowns and quarantine camps, these draconian restrictions that were trying to stop Covid. Now Chinese people are enjoying freedom and they're not threatened by these things. But everybody you talk to and their families, they all have Covid. One acquaintance describing walking down the street in Shanghai and she could see everybody kind of coughing on the street, recovering from this. The consequences are being felt beyond mainland China. Here in Hong Kong, my daughter got sick this week. You can't find throat lozenges here in pharmacies.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: You can't find fever medicine, like Tylenol, because it's all being  bought up and shipped to sick people in mainland China.Back to you guys.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Wow. Thank you, Ivan, very much.Kaitlan.
